title: Clefairy Almost Ruled the Pokémon World
fact: Before Pikachu became the icon, Clefairy was the top contender for the mascot role. They even considered Poliwhirl before Pikachu’s charm and universal appeal won them over.

title: The Real Meaning of Pokémon’s Name
fact: The name Pokémon is a cute shortening of 'Pocket Monsters' (ポケットモンスター), but only real pros know that it wasn’t just a random catchy name!

title: Tajiri's Bug-Fueled Genius
fact: Satoshi Tajiri, the creator of Pokémon, drew inspiration from his childhood obsession with catching insects. So next time you're hunting for bugs in the wild, think Pokémon!

title: Pikachu: Legal Tender Superstar
fact: Pikachu isn’t just a famous Pokémon; he’s also been featured on legal tender currency in Japan. That’s right—Pikachu’s a global superstar, even in banking!

title: Pikachu: Not Your Average Mouse
fact: Surprise! Pikachu was actually inspired by a squirrel, not a mouse. So next time you see one running around, maybe it’s secretly a Pikachu.

title: Pokémon Manhole Covers? Yes, Really!
fact: In Japan, you can find Pokémon-themed manhole covers (Pokéfuta), each featuring different Pokémon designs. It’s a quirky piece of Pokémon history you might just step on!

title: Slowbro: The Ultimate Devolution
fact: Did you know Slowbro can potentially devolve back to a Slowpoke? It’s a rare occurrence, but only real fans know about this strange and funky trait.

title: Pokémon Go 1 Billion Downloads Milestone
fact: Pokémon Go didn’t just take over the world—it’s been downloaded over 1 billion times! It’s the game that got everyone up and about, looking for Pokémon in the real world.

title: 1,000+ Pokémon: The Ever-Expanding Universe
fact: With over 1,000 species in the Pokémon world, you’d need multiple lifetimes just to catch ‘em all! And the best part? The new Pokémon keep coming.

title: Rhydon: The First Ever Pokémon Design
fact: Rhydon isn’t just another Rock/Ground-type—he was the very first Pokémon ever designed! That’s right, not even Pikachu had his spot in the drawing board first.
